2022. What can I say? From the loss of my father to the most important exhibition in my career you were a year of change to say the least. I look forward to next year with optimism, of course, but with this last year permanently tattooed on my brain as being one of those particular years of importance for all the right and all the wrong reasons. Thanks to everyone of you that continues this little journey with me, love you for all time. 😘😘 #robertszot #robszot #artist #art #painting #abstractart #abstractartist #abstractpainting #abstract #paper #artistsoninstagram #artcollector #artcurator #contemporaryart #losangeles #newyorkcity #2023

Special Music: Works on Paper
With master artist @robszot 

4 Tuesdays, January 17th - February 7th

Enroll now!

Starting with a day of mono print continue to build using a variety of mixed media techniques…

This workshop will cover topics like material choices, the importance of expanding your art practice, my collage and mixed media techniques, and applying ‘The Language Of Risk’ to your works on paper. At the heart of the program is the real-time process of starting a new work on paper and bringing that work to its conclusion at the end of the workshop.

#artacademy #abstractart #losangeles #artist #artistsoninstagram #artworkshop #klineacademy

I very excited to start the winter session of my painting workshop this Sunday (January 22nd) live via zoom from my studio in Los Angeles. This workshop is for all levels and my intention as always is not to teach you to paint like me but to introduce you to ideas and processes that I have developed over the last two decades of my artistic career. Make sure you sign up by this Saturday and receive my new 66 page ebook ONE HUNDRED THOUSAND HOURS for free. This ebook covers philosophy, processes, materials and a lot more and is a great standalone resource or an excellent companion to the workshop itself. LINK IN BIO. I’m so pleased to announce my new ebook ‘One Hundred Thousand Hours’ is now available to download. This 80+ page ebook is a comprehensive stand alone guide to all of my philosophies and techniques I use in my painting practice.  From materials to my custom painting medium, ‘One Hundred Thousand Hours’ walks you through the stages of a painting with the goal of adding these ideas and processes to your own artistic foundations.  This ebook focuses on asserting your individual voice into every work you produce and offers a clearer path to creating paintings that are unique and personal to you as an artist. I’m very proud of this little effort and think anyone from beginner to expert level artist will find something useful in its pages.  Let my 20+ years of trial and error in the studio answer some difficult questions and expand your practice as an artist. Ah the soft middle of a painting.  Often the most difficult time because it requires the elimination of parts of the work you probably like.  Editing out ideas you once thought were good in order to finish the painting in a more interesting way is important but never easy. #robertszot #robszot #artist #art #painting #abstractart #abstractartist #abstractpainting #abstract #paper #artistsoninstagram #artcollector #artcurator #contemporaryart #losangeles #newyorkcity

Subtracting layers of pigment from oil paint is a big part of my process. I begin every studio day by first spending an hour or so subtracting from the composition before I even pick up a paint brush. Subtraction not only produces depth and interesting relationships, this process allows me to reconnect and get reacquainted with the information from the day before #robertszot #robszot #artist #art #painting #abstractart #abstractartist #abstractpainting #abstract #paper #artistsoninstagram #artcollector #artcurator #contemporaryart #losangeles #newyorkcity

As I get nearer to completing a work the chaos and layering can feel a bit too overwhelming.  Losing confidence and forgetting the Object is a real danger at this stage. Slow down and focus on the overall picture and don’t mire down in details. If you’ve done the early development correctly the details will take care of themselves. #robertszot #robszot #artist #art #painting #abstractart #abstractartist #abstractpainting #abstract #paper #artistsoninstagram #artcollector #artcurator #contemporaryart #losangeles #newyorkcity

One Hundred Thousand Hours - The Program NOW AVAILABLE!  This newly completed program consists of 5 process videos with more than 2 hours of footage from inside my studio. These process videos will take you from the very beginning of my painting process all the way to a completed picture. Along the way I do deep dives into materials, processes, and techniques that I have developed over the past 20+ years of my career as a working artist, all demonstrated by me in the studio in this 5 video set. These videos are the most comprehensive insight to my painting practice I have ever produced and will provide step by step guidance and practical tools and tips for you to incorporate into your own artistic foundations. In addition to these videos you will also receive a digital copy of my 80+ page book ‘One Hundred Thousand Hours’ when you purchase ‘One Hundred Thousand Hours’ The Program. Thanks @pat_d for the music. So this is happening. Introducing Robert Szot Studio @robertszotstudio opening this week in Los Angeles. It will not only serve as my working studio but as a small exhibition platform and, perhaps most exciting, a venue to hold live Painting and Work On Paper workshops.  LIVE! Can you believe it? 

Not wanting to waste any time I have two painting workshops already slated for the month of April. Enrollment is limited to only 9 students per class so there is going to be a lot of one-on-one interaction and live demonstrations - direct from my working studio! 

Classes meet every week for the month of April and the first one starts April 3rd, so don't wait! 
LINK IN BIO

Workshop starts THIS SUNDAY!Enrollment is open for the Work On Paper - Spring Session 2023. Starting this Sunday (May 7th), and meeting live via Zoom for 4 weeks, this new workshop is going to be packed with information that will serve you for years to come. 

When I first ventured into working on paper I had very little concept of what it would eventually do to my career as a working artist, I was certain that my path was that of an oil painter and working in other mediums was only going to serve as a distraction and wasn't for me.  Needless to say I was very wrong and I am glad my stubbornness lost out to a more reasoned outcome. Working on paper has more than just expanded my vocabulary as an artist, it has redefined the way I work as a painter and more than doubled my collecting clientele.  Come join me this May and start reaping the benefits and experiencing the joys of working with this versatile medium.

PROCESS VIDEOS
In addition to the weekly Zoom sessions your enrollment will also include 4 in-depth PROCESS VIDEOS. This additional content will take deeper dives into each of the live sessions and will be posted each week following every Sunday Zoom call. 

ALL SESSIONS RECORDED
All Zoom sessions and Process Videos will be recorded - so if you can't make the live Sunday Session you can catch up when your schedule permits. The recorded content will be available for you to view for a full 6 months after the workshop ends on May 28th and you can watch and re-watch as much as you'd like.

Perfect for all levels of experience, the Work On Paper - Spring Session 2023 promises to be the most comprehensive and information rich workshop to date, so don't miss it. 

LINK IN BIO
See you Sunday!

Due to renewed interest I have located the original linocut blocks for this set of prints. Originally created in 2013, ‘3 Speeches’ was my very first venture into working on paper. Exhibited for the first and only time in New York City at the Muriel Guepin Gallery the original edition of 20 was never put up for public sale and only a few Artist Proofs made it into private hands. I have decided to reissue the edition of 20 and make them available for purchase.  Link In Bio if you’re interested in acquiring this little piece of my historical timeline. International shipping is available 😘😘

We meet every week (either Sunday or Tuesday) for a 3 hour in studio session focusing on mixed media works on paper. We run monoprints on the etching press and turn those prints into mixed media works of art. Limited to only 6 people per workshop there is a lot of opportunity for one on one discussion of both process and philosophy. It’s fun too promise. LINK IN BIO for more information and to sign up. ONLINE WORK ON PAPER WORKSHOP - All Live Sessions and All Process Videos Now Available Online! Over 5 hours of content from the studio - live demonstrations and in depth discussions on process, materials and philosophies. Expand your art practice with this ALL LEVEL online workshop. The videos will be available to watch any time until December 1 2023 so there is plenty of time to watch and re watch as you work!

I have set this program up with the intention of not only introducing you to my philosophy and approach to making art but also to take you along a journey as I start and work on a new mixed media work on paper, a work that will change before your very eyes as each week passes! We will also be discussing important topics ranging from the making of personal, individual-driven artwork to specific materials and philosophies. Each live session is now 75 minutes in length and every live session will have its own PROCESS VIDEO where I will record the practical application of that days topic in the studio.

LINK IN BIO. CLASSES START THIS SUNDAY! 

Join me LIVE in my Los Angeles studio for an ALL LEVEL PAINTING Workshop. This class will meet every SUNDAY or TUESDAY in JULY from 10am - 1pm PST in my new studio in Atwater Village in Los Angeles (3309 Glendale Blvd).

Limited to only 6 participants this class will take you from the very beginnings of my painting process through live demonstrations, utilizing philosophies like The Language Of Risk and Variety With Authorship, all the way through to the final stages of the work. Since the class is very limited in size we will be able to effectively dialogue with one another as we go through the stages of creating an abstract composition with a heavy emphasis on one-on-one interactions. Set in a fun and friendly environment this class will be free from the pressures of art school or more stuffy academically driven art classes and is appropriate for all levels of experience. My intention, as always, is not to teach you to paint like me, but rather offer you new insights into your own creative process through the introduction of new materials and techniques that I have worked to perfect in the 20+ years of my own professional artistic career.

I am looking forward to seeing you in my studio!

It’s always a bit difficult to pinpoint a time when your work shifts into some other gear. I think stylistic changes occur gradually and often over long periods of working. Major changes in habitual processes rarely just ‘appear’ and most times they creep in so quietly that someone else has to point out the change to you. That is why you should always be working, change is only achieved through prolonged searching. 😘😘 

Are You Really Really From The Ends?, oil and charcoal on linen, in the Brooklyn studio circa 2018

My work is all done in the moment and I never preplan. Planning kills options and I need to have as many options open to me when I work because of the way I work. Every move is a response to what I am processing in front of me. I work within the active dialogue I am having with my painting and the information I am receiving is real time and requires that I respond quickly. The result is work that frustrates and surprises in equal measure. It is a difficult way to work because you must first abandon any notion of a plan and accept that there is no clear path to a conclusion.

Sunday Service, oil on linen, in New York City circa 2017

Going away, Francis Bacon is the best painter. There is no separation between who he was and his work, which I think is the ultimate goal of any artist worth contemplating. We are all expressing ourselves, I guess, but how many really lay everything out for strangers to review? Not many. Egon Schiele falls in Bacon’s camp too. Philip Guston, who I mentioned earlier, ranks big for me. That guy changed direction midstream and didn’t care what people thought of it. That’s great stuff. Maybe it’s not the work so much that influences me, but the people who made it. Certainly, it is difficult to pull Francis Bacon out of one of my paintings. It’s chalk and cheese, but if I am lucky the approach is the same. I want the energy of a Francis Bacon, the recklessness of a Philip Guston, and the sorrow of a Mark Rothko to all come together in one frame, a terrible sucker punch that unfolds into a deeper story.

Loud Love (Study), mixed media and collage on paper, circa 2021

Fixing them helps me advance the painting as a whole, and my frustration with them provides a real velocity to the work. Starting a painting is very difficult for me because there is nothing to solve in a blank space.

There are so many ups and downs in one’s career that you must have faith in yourself and your vision to be able to push through the difficult times. There are a lot of difficult times too and you have to be ready to face them, learn from them and then move on from them. Without guidance or structure you have to have the confidence to navigate the deepest part of your uncertainties. It is a real battle and one you will never fully master. Even the successful moments often feel suspicious. 

Untitled, collage and mixed media on paper, circa 2017

I think the most difficult part is keeping oneself motivated. As a working artist no one, outside of an exhibition dead-line or a commission for a client, is going to make you work. You really have to continue in the face of complete silence at times and get comfortable with the desire to work just for the sake of working. The money will often be short, your work may or may not have an audience, the phone will stop ringing. You must acclimate yourself to a life of tremendous ups and downs and through it all you have to keep working and keep pushing that work as far as possible.

Untitled, oil and charcoal on linen, circa 2018

I have a disdain for what I call ‘idea art’. I am not someone who thinks of what a painting will look like beforehand or conceptualizes a game plan at the beginning of a project. I prefer work that draws you in further than something as plain as an idea. Work like that challenges the viewer’s certainties and makes them think harder about how they are responding to a painting. Without the instruction that an idea provides you have to give in to your subconscious in order to feel what something means as opposed to knowing it. Instinct is much more interesting than understanding. 

Hotpoint and Between Americans, both oil on linen mounted on panel, in the Brooklyn studio circa 2017

I don’t consider myself a painter that uses inspiration in the way you mean. My work is born from active problem solving. What I mean is that I respond to the ‘moment’ while I am working. If I create an interesting or even conflicting relationship in the composition I tend to exploit it immediately. So if there is any inspiration that is influencing me it happens very much in those little moments. I have often described my work as being kaleidoscopic in nature where one move opens up 10 others and so on. My work is the one informing me and seldomly if ever the other way around.

Composition 5, oil on canvas, circa 2009 (forgive the picture quality)

My days all seem the same to me. There is a lot of studio time and a lot of alone time. I prefer it that way though. I enjoy my longer days working but they all seem to run together. I hardly go out at night or even engage the city like I used to. The work has just taken over and its importance to me is above having a full social life. I think that is what it takes though, giving yourself over to just working. I mean I have friends but they rarely see me. It sounds grim but it isn’t really. I think they understand what I am doing.

yr boy and Early Voting, oil on linen, in New York City circa 2016

I find a lot of painters only using addition to solve compositional problems on their paintings.  Subtraction is often overlooked or regarded as a step backwards in the painting process.  I think that the thoughtful subtraction of information is vital to not only create interesting relationships between compositional elements but is a necessary step in order to make sure we are taking advantage of all the information we have added to the painting.  I will be discussing the advantages of Subtraction in the upcoming online painting workshop starting August 13th.  See you then! LINK IN BIO

I fell in love with painting when I stood in front of one and perceived that I could understand the person who made it and why it had to be made. I wanted to be a part of that. Just like everyone I’ve spent my life trying to be understood and I haven’t been very successful at it. I found with painting that it’s been a bit easier to communicate. Perhaps it’s because a painting demands audience participation or there is a bit of a mystery in a painting that brings people in and makes them want to understand. Maybe it’s because I eliminate conversation and a painting succeeds where my words fail. I don’t know but it’s something along those lines that makes painting seductive.
Plus I love painting. A painting is just for me, it’s mine alone until it goes out into the world. The act of painting is very selfish and I don’t care if it is. Art should be selfish. 

Study For Ofrenda

I’m currently leading an abstract painting workshop and demonstrating my process and materials, which still seems so different after spending 2 decades keeping these things to myself back in NYC. These pictures represent the first weeks of the 62 x 58 I am creating in the demonstration. The initial stages of all of my work deal almost exclusively with the flooding of the plane with interesting although somewhat unrelated chaos. The next stages involve the mitigation and arrangement of that early chaos in more compelling ways.

I began to deliberately break my paintings, putting large black lines through finished compositions.  I would now have to deal with the new chaos I had purposefully created for myself.  I would turn old paintings on their heads and dismantle them just to put them back together with more velocity and interest. I was an agent of chaos, creating problems just for the pleasure of solving them. Through this process I learned to trust my instincts to be able to fight through ‘mistakes’ in order to course correct.  I had become a thoughtful reactionary and it felt right. Suddenly I was back at the Metropolitan, standing in front of ‘Easter Monday’. The information flowed from that painting.  It had travelled fifty years just to have that one perfect moment with me.  When I got the smallest indication that my own work was communicating in the same way, I knew I was on to something that I would be chasing down for the rest of my life.

King Pink!, oil on linen, circa 2013

I have done my level best to rise above this din if for nothing else than to fulfill my own need to make the work I want to make. Abandoning current trends and what buyers and galleries clamoured for (I recall it was the desperate search for the next Basquiat when I arrived in NYC), I knew there were risks of dying on the vine by taking this approach. I didn’t care. I knew the only way to make myself truly bulletproof, to steel myself against critisism and back-biting, was to stay as true to my vision as I possibly could. That would require believing in myself. After all, I want to be in the mix, I want my work in exhibitions and I want to be a part of the conversation anytime someone is talking about contemporary art. Can the two of these rather opposing viewpoints ever meet in some impossibly happy middle ground? The answer is ‘yes’ because when you are the creator of singularities the world comes to you. What you make can not be repeated and that is your power. 
Beauty Culture, oil on linen mounted on panel, circa 2017

It has long been said that a person needs 10,000 hours to truly master something, and I believe it. Allow me to add that, within those long hours of work, a person must turn inward and view themselves from unfamiliar and often uncomfortable angles. True mastery of a subject comes not only from the complete understanding of how something is accomplished but also why that something is accomplished, and to reach that lofty airspace one must take deep dives into the subconscious and find ways to connect their individual voice directly to an external product. 

This is how all great art is created.

I want something more from my work, and from the work I see from other artists. I want to reintroduce consequence into my paintings and confront myself with difficult decisions. I want to be able to feel the work that went into something and to see how questions got raised and were answered all in the same moment. I don’t run away from the future and from what the future brings in terms of change, but art is nothing if there isn’t someone living inside of its compositions and colors. I am a creature of the studio and there, in that place, I paint the pictures of my life. 

The Dancer’s Beehive

oil, charcoal, gold and silver leaf on linen

My paintings always end in the same way, and always very suddenly. Weeks of concentration and hard graft will fall away and I will see the final move so clearly that it always surprises me. It is likely something small, a faint color shift using subtraction, maybe a line of charcoal or one last pass of a bar of black gesso. It is the best part of this job - that little end bit - the satisfying turn of the key and the feeling as the last tumbler in the lock drops. The door now opened, the ‘object’ is formed and full in its own knowing - all that work paying off right at the last moment. 
Through it all we have been, and not always consciously, asserting ourselves into our work. Challenging our own notions of familiarity through deliberate discord awakens new possibilities in creating art. Overcoming obstacles, self-imposed or otherwise, has given us a greater sense of confidence in our abilities. The work we are making speaks more about who we are through authorship, and that message will only get stronger as we make more work and flex our creative muscle through the implementation of variety. 

8 stages of The Dancer’s Beehive, 62 x 58, oil charcoal gold and silver leaf on linen, 2023

There will be difficulties, of course. Painting is fickle to put it mildly and, despite our best preparations, there is never any real telling where our work will take us. You must fight through these moments of uncertainty because, the reality is, there are ways around everything. Slow down and really look at what is in front of you. Let yourself become a reactionary painter; allow yourself the room to search and when you find that small ember of interest, react to it and turn it back into a full fire. You can do this, and maybe that isn’t something people hear enough. Hell, you’ve done this, so just keep doing it. Come back to these words if you need to, in those times when the phone isn’t ringing and it is just you in the studio. They will be here to remind you that what you are doing is meant to be difficult because doing anything so personal always is.

Fort Greene (Summer), collage, gold leaf and mixed media on joined paper, hanging in the Los Angeles studio 2023

I suppose the short answer is that you will never really know where your place is. Art is so broadly defined for such an esoteric act. It's so difficult to just motivate oneself to do it everyday much less take time out to assess where you stand in relation to other’s work. You might drive yourself crazy trying to sort it all. So my advice is just what I keep reminding myself of daily. You must learn to trust yourself implicitly and that you must always be challenging that trust in order to move the work forward. Everything is expendable, nothing you do is sacred. Change will keep you honest. It takes discipline and dedication and it hurts often but it is worth doing because there is nothing like finishing a painting that surprises you. Yes, even you, though it feels like you have seen and done everything.

The Head Of Bill De Kooning, monotype collage on joined paper, circa 2016

CLASSES START OCTOBER 8th! 

Join me LIVE in my Los Angeles studio for an ALL LEVEL PAINTING Workshop. This class will meet every SUNDAY or TUESDAY in October (starting October 8th) from 10am - 1pm PST in my studio in Atwater Village in Los Angeles (3309 Glendale Blvd).

Limited to only 5 participants per workshop this class will take you from the very beginnings of my painting process through live demonstrations, utilizing philosophies like The Language Of Risk and Variety With Authorship, all the way through to the final stages of the work. Since the class is very limited in size we will be able to effectively dialogue with one another as we go through the stages of creating an abstract composition with a heavy emphasis on one-on-one interactions. Set in a fun and friendly environment this class will be free from the pressures of art school or more stuffy academically driven art classes and is appropriate for all levels of experience. My intention, as always, is not to teach you to paint like me, but rather offer you new insights into your own creative process through the introduction of new materials and techniques that I have worked to perfect in the 20+ years of my own professional artistic career.

I am looking forward to seeing you in my studio!

Forget art school. Forget other artists. Forget your television and your phone. The studio and the work you produce should be your main concern. Everyone struggles to produce work and you should struggle, frankly, because it should always be a difficult thing to accomplish. The key is to never stop working.  A consistent studio practice, seriously LIVING in your studio, will eliminate any stumbling block or difficulty you may run into.  Even the opinions of other people become largely irrelevant if you are willing to commit nearly all of your time to your work.

Composition 6, oil on canvas, circa 2008.

I began painting in earnest when I was 23 years old. I had just returned from a trip to Florence, Italy and during that trip I had encountered the work of Egon Schiele for the first time. I remember thinking that here was a person who seemed to be able to express so much emotion with what I perceived to be a very small vocabulary.  Frankly I could not wrap my head around it. How could a single line or a seemingly simple application of gouache say such tremendous things? How could something talk about ecstasy and pain and beauty and yet feel so effortless? So my first canvases were my attempts to understand what I had seen mostly through replicating, quite poorly of course, Schiele’s most famous works.

CLASSES START NEXT WEEK! 

Join me LIVE in my Los Angeles studio for an ALL LEVEL PAINTING Workshop. This class will meet every SUNDAY or TUESDAY in October (starting October 8th) from 10am - 1pm PST in my studio in Atwater Village in Los Angeles (3309 Glendale Blvd).

Limited to only 5 participants per workshop this class will take you from the very beginnings of my painting process through live demonstrations, utilizing philosophies like The Language Of Risk and Variety With Authorship, all the way through to the final stages of the work. Since the class is very limited in size we will be able to effectively dialogue with one another as we go through the stages of creating an abstract composition with a heavy emphasis on one-on-one interactions. Set in a fun and friendly environment this class will be free from the pressures of art school or more stuffy academically driven art classes and is appropriate for all levels of experience. My intention, as always, is not to teach you to paint like me, but rather offer you new insights into your own creative process through the introduction of new materials and techniques that I have worked to perfect in the 20+ years of my own professional artistic career.

I am looking forward to seeing you in my studio!

I am at my best when I am problem solving. The challenge of ‘fixing’ something puts me at odds with conventional thinking and, frankly, keeps me from boring myself. Making decisions in sometimes difficult circumstances awakens my individuality. I have found a real velocity to my work when I put it in jeopardy through the intentional introduction of chaos into familiar situations. I cringe when I get into repetitive cycles, the comforts of past successes creeping into new work that I am desperate to push further. It is a common urge to wallow in familiar things but I don’t want to live there, despite how painful it is to go back into searching for that elusive ‘correctness’. So challenging myself through allowing for a bit of destruction has become common place in my studio practice. 

The important foil to this process is allowing yourself enough room to search for new answers. You have to mitigate your initial responses to self-introduced chaos, those early responses being things like panic or despair. I’ve definitely sweat my way through more than a few paintings, all because I did something counter-intuitive to my work in order for it to be a closer representation of who I am. Comfort is fine in every other aspect of my life, but not in my art. 

Solana, hanging in my current two-person exhibition with @creativebent in Los Angeles.

I am a believer in the notion that consistent work produces consistent work.  I am not directly influenced by anything - not consciously, anyway.  You must try to work everyday, even if you don’t feel particularly excited by the idea. The continuation of the dialogue between you and what you create is the only way to effectively produce personal and lasting images that speak about you directly. This is the way all great art is made.

I embrace change and use chaos as a way to convey movement and velocity.  I approach my paintings without preconceived notions or strict plans – I follow the work where it takes me, choosing to let color and composition inform me as opposed to bringing information to the work. There is obvious evidence of searching combined with a willingness to destabilize, utilizing risk and chaos to reach sometimes elusive conclusions. I choose colors intuitively, ignoring traditional tenets of color theory and more academic approaches to making art – the result is work that surprises, energizes, and transcends. Compositions come together to form images both harmonious and intrinsically moving, rewarding the viewer with a story that unfolds slowly in more personal and lasting ways. Combining variety with clear authorship - my goal is one of deep storytelling through communication in a visual language shared commonly among us. 

Notes For Gold, collage and mixed media on paper, hanging in my current two person exhibition with @creativebent in Los Angeles @robertszotstudio

I am not someone who thinks of what a painting will look like beforehand or conceptualizes a game plan at the beginning of a project. I prefer work that draws you in further than something as plain as an idea, work like that challenges the viewer’s certainties and makes them think harder about how they are responding to a painting. Without the instruction that an idea provides you have to give in to your subconscious in order to feel what something means as opposed to knowing it. Instinct is much more interesting than understanding.

The world is not made for artists, especially now. Society rewards speed and instant gratification over everything and that has a very specific consequence. People, and I include myself in this, are reluctant to allow themselves to search out answers and if a move or a decision isn’t instantly ‘correct’ it is viewed as error and lauded as a personal failure. 

‘Talent’ does not exist - it is something that is developed through searching and the repetition of a consistent work habit. Allow yourself the opportunity to ‘be good’ at something but don’t expect the results to be immediate. 😘😘

Jar, oil and charcoal on linen, from 2021.

2023 rolled in soon after my father’s passing and, facing such an enormous loss, I had never felt more uncertain about what this particular year had in store for me. I expected a challenge, and not a pleasant one. My life in New York City felt like a distant memory and Los Angeles loomed large and unfamiliar in front of me. I don’t deal with change very well.

This year transformed me as a person and as an artist in ways I was not fully expecting. Looking back at some of the major works I produced - they seem so different from anything I had done in years prior. They feel confident and knowing and, for perhaps the first time in my career, really speak about who I am and all the experiences I’ve been collecting for two decades. There is a comfortable nature to them and I find myself shocked at how precious each one is to me. If you know me at all you know I don’t think like this, it just isn’t in my nature to celebrate personal achievements. 

But 2023 was all about personal achievements. From my new studio in Los Angeles to embracing the idea of community and the sharing of my processes and artistic ideas. The people I’ve met and worked with this past year have opened my eyes to new possibilities. Inviting people into my art practice has rewarded me with a confidence that, until now, I was always so suspicious of. I am eternally grateful to everyone that has given me even a minute of their time in 2023. 

Thank you especially to @healingwithkari for carrying so much of my burden on her back these last few years, I love you and couldn’t have done anything without your support. Thank you to @anitarogersgallery and @elizagkirkpatrick for your continued efforts on my behalf and I look forward to 2024 with a lot of excitement and promise. 

Finally thank you Instagram community. Whether you have been with me for years or just a day I can’t tell you how much your continued support and interest in my very personal journey means to me. Love you forever. Happy new year. #robertszot #art #2023 #2024
Yes it’s New Year’s Day, yes I am working. 😘😘 #robertszot #art #2024

I’m excited to be kicking off 2024 with a new online painting workshop starting February 4th. We will meet every Sunday in February live from the studio where I will talk a little philosophy and begin a new abstract painting. The following weeks will take us through the entire process including the effective use of materials, utilizing risk and editing to our utmost advantage, and ways of dealing and communicating with galleries and clients. Let my 20 plus years of experience add to your own artistic foundations with what I think is a useful and fun 4 week workshop. 

In addition to the live sessions you will also get 4 accompanying process videos and a digital copy of my book One Hundred Thousand Hours which serves as an excellent companion to this particular workshop.
